RMSD.title: Root Mean Square Deviation (RMSD)
RMSD.content: Root Mean Square Deviation (RMSD) is a measure of the average distance between atoms of superimposed molecules. It is commonly used in structural biology to assess the similarity between structures. In the context of RNA, it quantifies how much the structure deviates from a reference structure as it change over time.

ERMSD.title: Escore Root Mean Square Deviation (eRMSD)
ERMSD.content: eRMSD is an extension of RMSD that enhances the sensitivity of RMSD measurements to structural rearrangements in RNA, providing more detailed information on RNA structural rearrangements by using RNA metrics rather than pure geometric ones.

CONTACT_MAPS.title: Contact Maps
CONTACT_MAPS.content: Contact maps represent the spatial proximity of pairs of residues (or atoms) within a structure, here shown as a 2D matrix. In RNA folding, they help visualize the formation of base pairs and interactions over time, reflecting how the structure is stabilizing.

TORSION.title: Torsional Angles
TORSION.content: Torsional angles describe the rotation around bonds, particularly useful in determining the flexibility and conformation of RNA structures. Monitoring these angles during structural rearrangements reveals how the structure transitions between different conformations.

SEC_STRUCTURE.title: Visualization for the current frame of the predicted secondary structure
SEC_STRUCTURE.content: The secondary structure is predicted using the Barnaba tool and visualized with Forna. This plot shows the base-pairing and stacking interactions, highlighting how the RNA folds into its secondary structure over time.

DOTBRACKET.title: Dot-Bracket Notation
DOTBRACKET.content: The dot-bracket notation is a compact way to represent the secondary structure of RNA, where dots represent unpaired bases, and parentheses represent paired bases. Here we're showing dotbracket notations found along the frames of the trajectory.

ARC.title: Arc Diagram
ARC.content: An arc diagram is a circular visualization used to represent base pairings in RNA secondary structures. Each base is positioned around the circle, and arcs are drawn to indicate paired bases, allowing for quick visualization of long-range interactions. Here we're computing them using barnaba

LANDSCAPE.title: Conformational Landscape
LANDSCAPE.content: The conformational landscape is a graphical representation of the system's conformational space as a function of structural coordinates (here RMSD, eRMSD, Torsion values or the fraction of natives contacts). It is used to identify stable states (minima) and transition states, providing insight into the behaviors of RNA.

BASE_PAIRING.title: Base Pairing
BASE_PAIRING.content: Base pairing refers to the hydrogen bonds between complementary nucleotides in RNA. This is crucial for secondary structure formation and stability. The plot shows the positions of the two bases in the base pairing, averaged for all the pairings , it mainly gives informations about the correctness of the ForceField and some specials pairings.

RADIUS_OF_GYRATION.title: Radius of Gyration
RADIUS_OF_GYRATION.content: The radius of gyration is a measure of RNA compactness, describing how far atoms are distributed from the molecule's center of mass. It provides insights into the overall size and shape changes during RNA folding, with smaller values indicating more compact conformations.

END_TO_END_DISTANCE.title: End-to-End Distance (5' to 3')
END_TO_END_DISTANCE.content: The end-to-end distance measures the spatial distance between the 5' and 3' terminal atoms of the RNA chain. This metric provides insights into RNA extension and compaction during folding, helping to understand how the RNA backbone extends or contracts over time.

PCA.title: Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
PCA.content: PCA is a dimensionality reduction technique that identifies here the principal components of structural variation in RNA conformations. It projects high-dimensional conformational data onto lower-dimensional space, revealing the main modes of structural variation during conformational changed.

UMAP.title: UMAP (Uniform Manifold Approximation)
UMAP.content: UMAP is a non-linear dimensionality reduction technique that preserves both local and global structure of conformational data. It provides a 2D representation of RNA conformational space, helping revealing clusters and transitions between different folding states.

TSNE.title: t-SNE (t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding)
TSNE.content: t-SNE is a non-linear dimensionality reduction method particularly effective at visualizing high-dimensional conformational data. It emphasizes local neighborhoods in the data, making it excellent for identifying distinct conformational clusters and folding intermediates.
